You obviously do not understand. Several countries, including Thailand have regulated industries that, in specific parts that aren't corrupted, have very low rates of disease when compared to unregulated parts of the industry. Manadatory condom usage, monthly testing, taxes. It appears many of the countries who do regualte actually make a sizable tax income off of legalization. Look at Las Vegas. Specific counties there legalize it. 
 

 
 Las Vegas is in Clark County, where prostitution is illegal. Nevada's code on prostitution makes it a county option, with that option going away when a county's population exceeds (I believe) 400,000. Clark County (Las Vegas) has the ability to amend that code, but a Clark County presence of the largest Mormon population outside of Utah would make it political suicide for any legislator attempting to do so. The result is a 1/2" section of yellow pages listing 'escort' services promising to fulfill any fantasy, street crime, expanded LE services and a gaping hole in potential tax revenue. The current mayor of Las Vegas has long promoted turning part of the eroding and seedy downtown section into an area of bordellos, but is unable to overcome the Mormon voting block (few of whom live downtown). 
 
 The city of Parump, about 60-miles from Las Vegas and in a county where prostitution is legal, has a constant, day and night stream of limos taking customers from the Vegas strip to Parump and then returning them. Those cities in counties with legalized prostitution regulate, value and support their bordellos. Those businesses contribute significant tax revenue, eliminate street crime, participate in community efforts and in general are good neighbors. The working girls are considered part of the community, just as they were in much of the US before 'sin' was turned into a political football supported by belief system leadership.

 The general public is far too apathetic and ignorant to realize what has happened to our fiscal well-being. Our politicians are still lying to them. They're living under the illusion that they're being protected from evil and fear is just as effective as prosperity when used as a governing tool. That we're creating that evil is lost on them. Until their standard of living is affected, and it will be, nothing will change. 
 
 I've mentioned on this forum before that my wife and I help support a charity kitchen. She also volunteers there helping serve food each Tuesday. We did the same thing in the last city we lived in. Patterns are recorded by attendance numbers. As we live in a colder climate, those numbers normally fall off during winter as the homeless migrate to warmer climates and then increase as warmer weather arrives. We've watched a steady increase in numbers all winter to the point where our facilities (seating 40) are now at two sittings, we're actively seeking additional volunteers and donations to expand for what looks like ongoing increases all year. Our homeless population has become permanent and will expand.
 
 While those who are destitute include a small percentage of mental causes and burned out drug addicts, what we're seeing in increases is former workers from unskilled to the middle class who lost jobs, couldn't replace them and ran out of resources. Our sheriff tells us there are semi-permanent encampments ranging from a few families to 50 and more people in the federal forests around us. The feds responsible for the forests have been stripped of operating money for all but revenue generating public parks, so unless marijuana is openly being cultivated in large quantities, enforcement is non-existent. 
 
 From what we experience and hear, the homeless situation is going to become far, far worse. I can go on, but, as mentioned, these things don't interest the average American glued to their entertainment screens. Until it personally affects them.
